data.name: XBreakIterator
desc: contains the base routines for iteration in Unicode string.
Iterates over characters, words, sentences and line breaks.
Assumption: StartPos is inclusive and EndPos is exclusive.

methods.name: beginOfCharBlock
desc: Traverses in Text from nStartPos to the beginning of the specified character type.

methods.name: beginOfScript
desc: Traverses in Text from nStartPos to the beginning of the specified script type.

methods.name: beginOfSentence
desc: Traverses in Text from nStartPos to the start of a sentence.

methods.name: endOfCharBlock
desc: Traverses in Text from nStartPos to the end of the specified character type.

methods.name: endOfScript
desc: Traverses in Text from nStartPos to the end of the specified script type.

methods.name: endOfSentence
desc: Traverses in Text from nStartPos to the end of a sentence.

methods.name: getLineBreak
desc: Calculate the line break position in the Text from the specified nStartPos.

methods.name: getScriptType
desc: Get the script type of the character at position nPos.

methods.name: getWordBoundary
desc: Identifies StartPos and EndPos of current word.

If nPos is the boundary of a word, it is StartPos of one word and EndPos of previous word. In this situation, the outcome of the algorithm can be indeterminate. In this situation the bPreferForward flag is used. If bPreferForward == FALSE, nPos is considered to be the end of the word and we look backwards for beginning of word, otherwise nPos is considered to be the start of the next word and we look forwards for the end of the word.

methods.name: getWordType
desc: This method is mis-defined, since WordType is not an attribute of a word, but a way to break words, like excluding or including tail spaces for spell checker or cursor traveling. It returns 0 always.

methods.name: isBeginWord
desc: If a word starts at position nPos.
It is possible that both of this method and following method isEndWord all return TRUE, since StartPos of a word is inclusive while EndPos of a word is exclusive.

methods.name: isEndWord
desc: If a word ends at position nPos.

methods.name: nextCharBlock
desc: Traverses in Text from nStartPos to the next start of the specified character type.

methods.name: nextCharacters
desc: Traverses specified number of characters/cells in Text from nStartPos forwards.
CharacterIteratorMode can be cell based or character based. A cell is made of more than one character.

methods.name: nextScript
desc: Traverses in Text from nStartPos to the next start of the specified script type.

methods.name: nextWord
desc: Traverses one word in Text from nStartPos forwards.

methods.name: previousCharBlock
desc: Traverses in Text from nStartPos to the previous start of the specified character type.

methods.name: previousCharacters
desc: Traverses specified number of characters/cells in Text from nStartPos backwards.
CharacterIteratorMode can be cell based or character based. A cell is made of more than one character.

methods.name: previousScript
desc: Traverses in Text from nStartPos to the previous start of the specified script type.

methods.name: previousWord
desc: Traverses one word in Text from nStartPos backwards.

If the previous character is a space character and nWordType indicates spaces should be skipped, and if the first non-space character is an Asian character, then, since Asian word break needs language specific wordbreak dictionaries, the method will return -1 in Boundary.endPos() and the position after the Asian character (i.e. the space character) in Boundary.startPos(). The caller then has to call this method again with a correct aLocale referring to the Asian character, which is then the previous character of the space character where nStartPos points to.
Note that the OpenOffice.org 1.0 / StarOffice 6.0 / StarSuite 6.0 i18n framework doesn't behave like this and mixed Western/CJK text may lead to wrong word iteration. This is fixed in later versions.
